def.usage: 안녕하세요? is a greeting that asks about the other persons well-being or good health. This expression can be used at any time of the day as "Good morning." "Good afternoon." "Good evening." "Hi." "Hello." or "How is it going?" The common response is simply 네, 안녕하세요?.

새끼 "baby animal" and 자식 "human baby" are used in Korean slang the way "asshole" is used in American English. When said to one's closest friends, they can be expressions of affection - but handle with care.

head.k: - Yeah, Peter and Mary are fine.
Are you making fun of me?
It's got nothing to do with me.
Make it cheaper and I'll buy it.
When is it good for you?
What time is good for you?
How about the day after tomorrow?
What time will we be back?

def.usage: Literally means "Can you hear my voice clearly?"

head.k: I don't understand what you're saying.
You shouldn't say things like that.

def.dtrn: 난 그런 말 한 적 없어.

head.k: I don't want to talk with you.
I don't want to hear about it.
I don't want to hear about that thing.
I don't want to see it.
I want to see you soon.
Are you going to meet Jinju soon?
- I'm going to meet Jinju soon.
I want to go to Seoul.
I really don't want to go.

def.usage: Literally means "I'm dying from hunger; I'm crazy from hunger."

head.k: Do you want to eat something?
I want to drink some beer.
I think this has gone bad.
Do you want to drink some more?
- Thank you, but I still have plenty.
Come on, dude, have some more!

def.usage: A formulaic phrase used when one is invited for dinner.

head.k: I'd like to try some boshingtang*.

def.usage: * Rice cake mixed with hot chilly paste and vegetables.

head.k: That's a dip, don't drink it!

def.usage: Literally means "I don't know which is which."
Literally means "I left!"; to much alcohol, too many parties...
My head''s going "ping!" i.e. it's spinning.
Literally means "Why are you looking down on me?"
Literally means "Other person." The idea is: "That is the kind of question you could ask yourself, but I'm not you - so it's none of your business!"
Literally means "Kick penis!" From 좆, "penis", and 까, "kick".

head.k: Do you know who I am?
Come here, I'll teach you some manners!

def.usage: Literally means "You have no manners, baby; come here!"

head.k: Go drink your mother's breast milk and then come back!

def.dtrn: 가서 엄마 젖이나 더 먹고 와!

def.usage: Implies that the person being insulted is so unseemly that the speaker's stomach is turning.

head.k: Why don't you go somewhere and die!
You look like you're having fun.
Can I buy you a drink?
Wow, what a nice job you've got!
What kinds of hobbies do you have?
- This is the first time I'm hearing it.
What time do you have to be home!
Do you wanna come to my place?
I want to know more about you.
When can I see you again?
This is Robert. Is Mary at home?

def.usage: Literally means "Stay well" usually said by the person who called.

head.k: Do you wanna sleep with me?

def.usage: The Korean word 팬티, despite its derivation from English "panty" is gender-neutral.

head.k: I don't like to wear a condom.
If you don't wear a condom, I won't do it!
I don't want to get married yet.
I love you, but I can't become your wife/husband.

def.dtrn: 날 사랑하지만, 네 아내 는 / 남편은될 수 없어.
우리 더 생각해 봐야 될 거 같애.

head.k: Do you want to come to ... with me?
I want to stay in Korea.
Let's not see each other again.
I'll call you when I come back.
